name: hill
content:
hill

noun
 
 
/hɪl/
 
/hɪl/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     
     [countable] an area of land that is higher than the land around it, but not as high as a mountain
    • a region of gently rolling hills
    • a hill farm/town/fort
    • on a hill The church is perched on a hill.
    • The house is built on the side of a hill overlooking the river.
    • up a hill They make their way up the hill.
    • down a hill We started to walk back down the hill.
    • in the hills I love walking in the hills (= in the area where there are hills).
    • They stopped at the top of the hill to admire the view.
    • A spring emerges at the bottom of the hill.
    see also anthill, foothill, molehill
    Extra Examples
    • A grassy path led down the hill.
    • Olive groves cover the hills.
    • Over the hill lies another town.
    • The landscape is made up of low, rolling hills.
    • The town is set on a small hill.
    • There are several lead mines in the hills above Grassington.
    • They climbed a steep hill and came to the town.
    • They crested a small hill and then the path curved.
    • Troops forced villagers to flee to the surrounding hills.
    • We took to the hills in a variety of four-wheel-drive vehicles.
    • Wooded hills rise behind the town.
    • a hill overlooking the wide valley below
    • the chalk hills of southern England
    • the distant blue hills
    • the houses which dotted the hill
    • the limestone hills of Kentucky
    Topics Geographya2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • big
    • high
    • long
    • …
    verb + hill
    • ascend
    • climb
    • climb up
    • …
    hill + verb
    • overlook something
    • rise
    • surround something
    • …
    hill + noun
    • climbing
    • walking
    • climb
    • …
    preposition
    • down a/​the hill
    • in the hills
    • on a/​the hill
    • …
    phrases
    • the bottom of a/​the hill
    • the foot of a/​the hill
    • the crest of a/​the hill
    • …
    See full entry
  2.  
     [countable] a slope on a road
    • up a hill The motorcade made its way up the hill.
    • down a hill Always take care when driving down steep hills.
    • a hill start (= the act of starting a vehicle on a slope)
    see also downhill, uphill
    Extra Examples
    • I had to do a hill start.
    • The bus sped down the long hill.
    • A few yards up the hill, on the left, was a turning.

  3. the Hill
     [singular] (North American English, informal) Capitol Hill (= used to refer to the US Capitol and the activities that take place there)
    4. Word OriginOld English hyll, of Germanic origin; from an Indo-European root shared by Latin collis and Greek kolōnos ‘hill’.
Idioms
as old as the hills
  1. very old; ancient
    More Like This Similes in idiomsSimiles in idioms
    • (as) bald as a coot
    • (as) blind as a bat
    • (as) bright as a button
    • (as) bold as brass
    • as busy as a bee
    • as clean as a whistle
    • (as) dead as a/​the dodo
    • (as) deaf as a post
    • (as) dull as ditchwater
    • (as) fit as a fiddle
    • as flat as a pancake
    • (as) good as gold
    • (as) mad as a hatter/​a March hare
    • (as) miserable/​ugly as sin
    • as old as the hills
    • (as) pleased/​proud as Punch
    • as pretty as a picture
    • (as) regular as clockwork
    • (as) quick as a flash
    • (as) safe as houses
    • (as) sound as a bell
    • (as) steady as a rock
    • (as) thick as two short planks
    • (as) tough as old boots
a hill of beans
  1. (North American English, old-fashioned, informal) something that is not worth much
over the hill
  1. (informal) (of a person) old and therefore no longer useful or attractive
    • Youngsters seem to think you're over the hill at 40!
See hill in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee hill in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: hill
matches: There is a green hill far away
relatives: There is a green hill far away

name: Nob Hill
content:
Nob Hill

 
/ˌnɒb ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌnɑːb ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. a fashionable district of San Francisco, California. It includes Grace Cathedral and two famous hotels, the Fairmont and the Mark Hopkins. Many of the large Victorian houses originally built there by rich people, or ' nobs', were destroyed by the fire that followed the 1906 earthquake (= sudden, violent movement of the earth's surface).
Check pronunciation: Nob Hill

name: Boot Hill
content:
Boot Hill

noun
 
/ˌbuːt ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌbuːt ˈhɪl/
[uncountable] (US English, informal, humorous)
jump to other results
  1. (in the Wild West) a place where people are buried
    CultureOne of the best known is at Tombstone, Arizona. The name comes from the idea that many people were buried in the boots they were wearing when they were killed.
See Boot Hill in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Boot Hill

name: Beacon Hill
content:
Beacon Hill

noun
 
/ˌbiːkən ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌbiːkən ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. an old, fashionable area of Boston in the US, where many rich families and politicians live
See Beacon Hill in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Beacon Hill

name: Fanny Hill
content:
Fanny Hill

 
/ˌfæni ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌfæni ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. a novel (1749) by John Cleland (1707-89) about the sexual adventures of a young woman in 18th-century London. Its original title was Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure. The book was banned in Britain when a company tried to publish it in 1963, and became very popular when it was finally published in 1970.
Check pronunciation: Fanny Hill

name: Grange Hill
content:
Grange Hill

 
/ˌɡreɪndʒ ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌɡreɪndʒ ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. a British children's television programme which started in the 1970s. It was set in a school in London, and was more realistic than many children's programmes, dealing with problems such as bullying.
Check pronunciation: Grange Hill

name: Benny Hill
content:
Benny Hill

 
/ˌbeni ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌbeni ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. (1925-92) an English comedy actor popular from the middle of the 1950s to the 1980s. His television series The Benny Hill Show, which he wrote himself, consisted mainly of clever visual humour and jokes about sex which some people considered old-fashioned.
Check pronunciation: Benny Hill

name: Tower Hill
content:
Tower Hill

 
/ˌtaʊə ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌtaʊər ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. an area of high ground close to the Tower of London where in former times certain prisoners held in the Tower, especially the most famous and important ones, were executed by having their heads cut off
Check pronunciation: Tower Hill

name: Capitol Hill
content:
Capitol Hill

noun
 
/ˌkæpɪtl ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌkæpɪtl ˈhɪl/
(also informal the Hill)
[singular]
jump to other results
  1. used to refer to the US Capitol and the activities that take place there
See Capitol Hill in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Capitol Hill

name: Rowland Hill
content:
Rowland Hill

 
/ˌrəʊlənd ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌrəʊlənd ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. (1795-1897) a British Post Office worker who invented the postage stamp, originally costing one penny (the Penny Black, introduced in 1840). Before this, postage was paid by the person receiving a letter or parcel. Hill was made a knight in 1860.
Check pronunciation: Rowland Hill

name: hill station
content:
hill station

noun
 
/ˈhɪl steɪʃn/
 
/ˈhɪl steɪʃn/
jump to other results
  1. a small town in the hills, especially in South Asia, where people go to find cooler weather in summer
    • In the heat of summer the rich fled to the hill stations.
Check pronunciation: hill station

name: Notting Hill
content:
Notting Hill

 
/ˌnɒtɪŋ ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌnɑːtɪŋ ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. a fashionable area of west London. It is especially famous for the Notting Hill Carnival, a colourful street festival held there every year on the August Bank Holiday.
Check pronunciation: Notting Hill

name: Silbury Hill
content:
Silbury Hill

 
/ˌsɪlbri ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌsɪlbəri ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. a prehistoric mound (= raised mass of earth) near Avebury in south-west England, built before 2000 BC. It is the largest of these mounds in Europe, and, unlike most of the others, has nobody buried in it. Nobody knows what it was built for.
Check pronunciation: Silbury Hill

name: Strawberry Hill
content:
Strawberry Hill

 
/ˌstrɔːbəri ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌstrɔːberi ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. a large house by the Thames, west of London, well known for its Gothic architecture. Horace Walpole bought the house in 1749 and added several towers and detailed and complicated decorations. It is one of the earliest examples of the Gothic Revival, and the style of architecture which it influenced is sometimes referred to as 'Strawberry Hill Gothic'.
Check pronunciation: Strawberry Hill

name: George Roy Hill
content:
George Roy Hill

 
/ˌdʒɔːdʒ rɔɪ ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌdʒɔːrdʒ rɔɪ ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. (1922-2002) a US film director. His best-known films include Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969), The Sting (1973), for which he won an Oscar, and The World According to Garp (1982).
Check pronunciation: George Roy Hill

name: the Battle of Bunker Hill
content:
the Battle of Bunker Hill

 
/ðə ˌbætl əv ˌbʌŋkə ˈhɪl/
 
/ðə ˌbætl əv ˌbʌŋkər ˈhɪl/
jump to other results
  1. the first major battle of the American Revolution. It is named wrongly because the battle was actually fought on Breed's Hill. It was on 17 June 1775 near Boston. Although the British won, the Americans were encouraged because they fought well and killed many British soldiers until they had used all their bullets.
Check pronunciation: the Battle of Bunker Hill

name: There is a green hill far away
content:
There is a green hill far away

 
/ðeər ˌɪz ə ˌɡriːn hɪl ˌfɑː əˈweɪ/
 
/ðer ˌɪz ə ˌɡriːn hɪl ˌfɑːr əˈweɪ/
jump to other results
  1. the first line of a well-known Christian hymn (= religious song) traditionally sung at Easter
Check pronunciation: There is a green hill far away
nearBys: There is a green hill far away

name: bean
content:
bean

noun
 
 
/biːn/
 
/biːn/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     
     a seed, or pod containing seeds, of a climbing plant, eaten as a vegetable. There are several types of bean and the plants that they grow on are also called beans.
    • green beans
    • runner beans
    • beans (= baked beans) on toast
    • a can/tin of beans
    • She grows her own broad beans.
    see also snap beanTopics Fooda2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • broad
    • butter
    • chilli
    • …
    verb + bean
    • plant
    • grow
    • drain
    • …
    bean + noun
    • curd
    • sprout
    See full entry
  2.  
     (usually in compounds) a seed from a coffee plant, or some other plants
    • cocoa/coffee beans
    Topics Farmingb1 see also jelly bean
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • castor
    • cocoa
    • coffee
    • …
    verb + bean
    • roast
    • grind
    See full entry
    3. Word OriginOld English bēan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch boon and German Bohne.
Idioms
full of beans/life
  1. (of a person) having a lot of energy
a hill of beans
  1. (North American English, old-fashioned, informal) something that is not worth much
not have a bean
  1. (British English, informal) to have no money
not know beans about something
  1. (North American English, informal) to know nothing about a subject
    • I don’t know beans about making movies.
spill the beans
  1. (informal) to tell somebody something that should be kept secret or private
See bean in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: bean
